text: Virtual reality cinema has been booming since 2014 and is generating more and more interest in the film industry. It also raises a number of new forms of questioning about cinema. The purpose of this conference is to reveal some of these questions, creative and technical, with a view to an approach to this emerging new cinematographic form.
post_text: Virtual reality cinema has been booming since 2014 and is generating more and more interest in the film industry. It also raises a number of new forms of questioning about cinema. The purpose of this conference is to reveal some of these questions, creative and technical, with a view to an approach to this emerging new cinematographic form.

October 19, 2019 at 9:30 AM Â·
As part of the Carthage Film Festival (JCC), Carthage Digital is our new born. Uniting artists, producers, content creators, distributors, investors, festival programmers and tech leaders that are exploring new forms of storytelling and immersive production, for a multitude of networking, financing and distribution opportunities with international digital industry world players.
For the first time at the JCC, Carthage Digital runs an original program with new dimensionsâ€™ focus on other forms of cinematographic images made of works showcases, and technologies highlights. text:
The Carthage Film Festival JCC will host Cinephilia Shorts Lab in October. Launched in 2013, Cinephilia Shorts Lab is a 12-day intensive writing program designed to assist filmmakers in developing their storytelling potential, criticism faculty and technical proficiency.
Cinephilia Shorts Lab aims to develop original, visionary and daring voices in the art of screenwriting from the Middle East and Africa.
The lab offers the tools that result in a strong narrative short film while focusing on the individual's unique voice as screenwriter and by connecting like-minded people through shared collaborative feedbacks.
Cinephilia Productions #jcc2019 #carthagepro
CINEPHILIAPRODUCTIONS.COM
CALL FOR APPLICATIONS: CINEPHILIA SHORTS LAB, TUNISIA 2019 â€” Cinephilia Productions

text:
In memory of Nejib Ayed, may he rest in peace?
When Great Trees Fall
By Maya Angelou
When great trees fall,
rocks on distant hills shudder,
lions hunker down
in tall grasses,
and even elephants
lumber after safety.
When great trees fall
in forests,
small things recoil into silence,
their senses
eroded beyond fear.
When great souls die,
the air around us becomes
light, rare, sterile.
We breathe, briefly.
Our eyes, briefly,
see with
a hurtful clarity. â€¦

text:
PRESS RELEASE
Following the vile attack perpetrated on Monday October 29, 2018 in the heart of Tunis, NÃ©jib Ayed and the Organizing Committee of the Carthage Film Festival condemn with the greatest virulence the terrorist and cowardly act that targeted Tunis, a few days before the opening of the festival.
Just like Tunisia, the JCC as a place of freedom and resistance will not bend to the bearers of obscurantist projects and true to our convictions, we will continue to proclaim loud and clear that only culture is an impassable barrier against ignorance and deadly projects.
Terrorism today is a global phenomenon and unfortunately nobody is immune.
But the festival will take place and we will celebrate the values of tolerance, openness and life over nihilism.
#JCC2018 #NoPasaran

Wednesday, August 15, 2018: Last day of film registrations for the next session of the Carthage film Festival, official competition.
Here are the numbers:
Total number of films received (feature film + short film, fiction and documentaries): 433
Feature films: 123, including 16 Tunisian films
Short films: 310, including 45 Tunisian films
Number of countries: 37 countries: 16 Arab countries and 21 African countries

text:
Press release
It is with great concern that the Carthage Film Festival has heard the news of the suspension for the year 2018 of the Dubai International Film Festival DIFF.
At a time when Arab filmmakers, producers and creators are standing out in the most prestigious international film festivals, the Arab art scene needs more than ever local and regional platforms so that professionals and national viewers can have access to their production and DIFF has played a vital role in this direction since its inception in 2004.
Hoping that this suspension is only temporary and that Dubai will come back with even more strength and presence, the Carthage Film Festival will continue to campaign for a rich, independent, varied and militant Arab film industry, that carries values of progress and tolerance.
Nejib Ayed
Director General
post_text:
Press release
It is with great concern that the Carthage Film Festival has heard the news of the suspension for the year 2018 of the Dubai International Film Festival DIFF.
At a time when Arab filmmakers, producers and creators are standing out in the most prestigious international film festivals, the Arab art scene needs more than ever local and regional platforms so that professionals and national viewers can have access to their production and DIFF has played a vital role in this direction since its inception in 2004.
Hoping that this suspension is only temporary and that Dubai will come back with even more strength and presence, the Carthage Film Festival will continue to campaign for a rich, independent, varied and militant Arab film industry, that carries values of progress and tolerance.
Nejib Ayed
Director General

http://e-festivals.tn/

text:
Lately, weâ€™ve been hearing a lot about Categories for Film Festivals.
Cannes since 1946 or Cairo since 1975 are Category A festivals, Namur is category B.
The International Federation of Film Producers Associations (FIAPF), dominated by the American Majors, created the categorization system according to a number of criteria, the main ones being the value of the first prize, a local film industry and agreeing to pay a hefty fee in order to be on this â€œprestigious listâ€.
But how about the Carthage Film Festival?
As the dean of film festivals in Africa and the Arab world, our festival was established in 1966 as the forum for emerging African and Arab cinemas. We made the immediate choice not toâ€¦ More

Inside the Carthage Film Festival After the Tunis Suicide Bombing | VICE | United States

text:
The Carthage staff handled the crisis with admirable aplomb, and their ability to rearrange most scheduled evening screenings to other times owing to a 9 p.m. curfew was impressive. Even more striking was the enthusiasm of the audiences, who packed the large, single-screen cinemas downtown both before and after the attack, undeterred in their zeal particularly for local fare: no wonder the festival, now in its 26th edition, changed in 2014 from every other year to an annual event. Any film festival would give its eye teeth for the kind of loyal, energetic crowds at Carthage, encapsulated by the mobbed screening for Nabil Ayouchâ€™s controversial â€œMuch Loved.â€ Local authorities feared some kind of clash might ensue given the filmâ€™s sexual content, erecting barriers and increasing police presence, but it was a peaceful screening, and reminded this jaded critic that especially in these uncertain times, cinema matters. #JCC2015
VARIETY.COM
Cairo and Carthage: How Mid-East Film Festivals Deal With Terrorism, Freedom

text:
Teenagers and JCC
Chahrazed Bouarada â€“ LycÃ©e Bchir Nebheni Hamam Lif






First of all , I want to thank all ofthe security guards and the organizers of this yearâ€™s JCC who made sure toprepare a safe and ordered environment for the audience . Also, I want to thankthe spectators who attended to this event in spite of the threatening eventsthat have been happening lately .
To be honest I had low expectations from thisyearâ€™s JCC, I heard that last year, the lack of organization and securityruined the event. But it wasnâ€™t the case for last Sunday .
Unfortunately , there wasnâ€™t enough time to doanything , the period between each movie was only enough for going from onemovie theatre to another . In addition, I noticed that most of the audiencewere teenagers . Not only did they run for the door the moment they walked in_because certain movies didnâ€™t interest them _ , but also they couldnâ€™t watchall of the movies because many of them ended very late . I think they shouldhave arranged the program so it would go with the teensâ€™ schedule .
In summary , this yearâ€™s JCC is so far so good .The only problem is the timing .
